Title.evidence: This retrospective observational study investigated medium-term restenosis rates between commercially available biological and synthetic carotid patches.

Trial_Design.evidence: This retrospective observational study investigated medium-term restenosis rates between commercially available biological and synthetic carotid patches.

Participants.evidence: All primary CEA with patch angioplasty performed between 2007 and 2019 at a single university hospital were identified from theatre records.

Intervention.evidence: Chi-square tests and Kaplan-Meier curves were used to compare restenosis rates between biological (bovine pericardium) and synthetic patches (Dacron, PFTE and polyester-urethane).

Objective.evidence: This retrospective observational study investigated medium-term restenosis rates between commercially available biological and synthetic carotid patches.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Restenosis was defined using the European Society for Vascular Surgery duplex criteria, either moderate (50–69%, PSV >213cm/s) or critical (70–99%, PSV >274cm/s).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Overall, 127 CEAs were included in the restenosis analysis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Compared with synthetic material, bovine was significantly associated with >50% restenosis but not >70% ( p =0.042 and p =0.197, respectively).

Harms.evidence: There was no significant difference in peri-operative complication rates between patch types.
